title: Scientific Calculator
description: Free online scientific calculator with trigonometric, logarithmic, and exponential functions. Supports degrees and radians, memory functions, calculation history, and all standard mathematical operations.

meta.title: Scientific Calculator - Free Online Advanced Math Calculator
meta.description: Free online scientific calculator with sin, cos, tan, log, ln, square root, and more. Supports degrees/radians mode, memory functions, and calculation history. Perfect for students and professionals.
meta.keywords: scientific calculator, online calculator, sin cos tan calculator, logarithm calculator, square root calculator, advanced calculator, math calculator, trigonometry calculator

disclaimer.text: This scientific calculator is provided for educational and informational purposes. While we strive for accuracy, always verify critical calculations.
disclaimer.note: For complex calculations, consider using specialized software or consulting a professional.

seo.whatIsContent: A scientific calculator is an advanced mathematical tool that goes beyond basic arithmetic to handle complex mathematical functions. Unlike simple calculators, scientific calculators support trigonometric functions (sin, cos, tan), logarithms, exponents, roots, factorials, and more. Our free online scientific calculator brings all these capabilities to your browser, making it perfect for students, engineers, scientists, and anyone who needs advanced mathematical computations.
seo.featuresIntro: Our scientific calculator includes all the functions you need for advanced mathematics:
seo.feature1: Trigonometric functions: sin, cos, tan and their inverse functions
seo.feature2: Logarithmic functions: log (base 10) and ln (natural logarithm)
seo.feature3: Power and root operations: squares, cubes, nth power, square root, cube root
seo.feature4: Mathematical constants: π (Pi) and e (Euler's number)
seo.feature5: Memory functions: M+, M-, MR, MC for storing and recalling values
seo.feature6: Calculation history: Review and reuse previous calculations
seo.howToUseTitle: How to Use the Scientific Calculator
seo.howToUseStep1: Select your angle mode (DEG for degrees or RAD for radians) if using trigonometric functions
seo.howToUseStep2: Enter numbers using the digit buttons or your keyboard
seo.howToUseStep3: Select operations and functions by clicking the corresponding buttons
seo.howToUseStep4: Use parentheses to control the order of operations for complex expressions
seo.howToUseStep5: Press = or Enter to calculate the result
seo.tip1: Use the 2nd button to access inverse trigonometric functions (sin⁻¹, cos⁻¹, tan⁻¹)
seo.tip2: The Ans button inserts the previous result into your current expression
seo.tip3: Memory functions (M+, M-, MR, MC) let you store values for later use
seo.tip4: The History panel shows all your previous calculations for easy reference
seo.tip5: Use keyboard shortcuts for faster input: numbers, +, -, *, /, Enter, Escape
seo.faq1Question: What's the difference between DEG and RAD mode?
seo.faq1Answer: DEG (degrees) mode interprets angle values as degrees (0-360°), while RAD (radians) mode interprets them as radians (0-2π). For example, sin(90) in DEG mode equals 1, while sin(π/2) in RAD mode also equals 1. Use DEG for everyday calculations and RAD for calculus and advanced mathematics.
seo.faq2Question: How do I calculate square roots and cube roots?
seo.faq2Answer: Click the √ button for square root or use sqrt(number). For cube root, use the ∛ button or cbrt(number). For nth roots, use the power function with a fractional exponent: x^(1/n).
seo.faq3Question: What is the difference between log and ln?
seo.faq3Answer: log is the common logarithm (base 10), used in engineering and general calculations. ln is the natural logarithm (base e ≈ 2.718), used in calculus, physics, and continuous growth calculations. Example: log(100) = 2, while ln(e) = 1.
seo.faq4Question: How do I use the memory functions?
seo.faq4Answer: M+ adds the current display value to memory. M- subtracts from memory. MR recalls the stored memory value. MC clears the memory. These are useful for multi-step calculations where you need to store intermediate results.
seo.faq5Answer: Yes! Use numbers 0-9 for digits, +, -, *, / for operations, Enter or = for equals, Escape for clear, Backspace to delete the last character, and parentheses ( ) for grouping.
seo.faq6Question: What is factorial (n!) and when do I use it?
seo.faq6Answer: Factorial (n!) is the product of all positive integers up to n. For example, 5! = 5×4×3×2×1 = 120. It's used in probability, permutations, combinations, and statistics. Our calculator supports factorials up to 170!
seo.faq7Question: How does order of operations work?
seo.faq7Answer: The calculator follows standard mathematical order of operations (PEMDAS): Parentheses first, then Exponents, then Multiplication and Division (left to right), then Addition and Subtraction (left to right). Use parentheses to override the default order.
seo.faq8Question: What are π (Pi) and e (Euler's number)?
seo.faq8Answer: π (Pi ≈ 3.14159) is the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter, essential for geometry and trigonometry. e (Euler's number ≈ 2.71828) is the base of natural logarithms, fundamental in calculus, compound interest, and exponential growth calculations.
